title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and highlights the unseen world of data centers with a focus on AI and creative practice. The description points viewers to the full episode on the channel and frames AI/data infrastructure as central to modern creativity.
bullets: Accompanies Season 5 of the podcast Where the Internet Lives (Webby Award–winning).
Focuses on the unseen infrastructure of data centers and the role of AI in creativity.
No transcript provided in the supplied materials.
Directs viewers to watch the full episode on the channel; uses hashtags #WhereTheInternetLives #AI #Data #Creativity.
takeaways: AI-driven creative workloads increase compute and energy demand — plan capacity, flexible scaling, and cooling upgrades accordingly.
Data center expansion for AI should be paired with efficiency measures (cooling, PUE) to manage operational costs and grid impact.
Integrate on-site or contracted renewables and storage to support sustainability targets and improve resilience against grid disturbances.
Assess supply-chain and lifecycle needs for accelerators and related hardware (including critical minerals and recycling strategies) when forecasting procurement.

items.title: Super charging creativity | Where the Internet Lives

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this short film from Google’s Where the Internet Lives series profiles emerging artist Will Hatcher (King Willonious) and his portable creative studio, showing how AI can be used to expand equity, imagination, and reinvention in the creative process. The episode sits within a data-center–focused series and positions cloud/AI tools as enablers of new creative workflows.
bullets: Profiles artist Will Hatcher (King Willonious) and his full creative studio-in-a-backpack.
Explores AI as a tool for equity, imagination, and radical reinvention of creative practice.
Part of the Webby Award–winning Where the Internet Lives series about data centers.
Frames cloud and AI services as enablers of portable, modern creative workflows.
Links to Google Data Centers resources and additional seasons of the series.
takeaways: AI-driven creative workflows showcased imply growing reliance on cloud compute — plan capacity and scaling strategies accordingly.
Portable, cloud-enabled studios increase distributed demand patterns; consider network bandwidth and edge connectivity implications for substations and last-mile infrastructure.
Framing AI as an equity tool suggests demand for accessible, resilient cloud services — prioritize redundancy and reliable power for critical access points.
Sustaining increased AI and creative workloads supports the case for low-carbon energy sourcing and energy-efficiency measures at data centers.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno (Google Cloud) outlines how AI-aware networking—centered on the GKE Inference Gateway and Cloud Load Balancing—optimizes inference routing to improve GPU utilization, cut latency and reduce cold starts. The approach uses inference-specific metrics, prefix caching, body-based routing and service extensions to insert API management and guardrails into the traffic path.
bullets: Uses inference-specific metrics (e.g., KV cache utilization, queue depth) to route to the least-loaded replicas rather than relying on CPU-based or round-robin methods.
Prefix caching and shadow copies let the gateway reuse prefill computations to reduce GPU work and minimize cold starts.
Body-based routing and LoRA-adapter awareness enable model- and adapter-specific traffic routing for mixed-model deployments.
Service Extensions allow insertion of API management and AI guardrails at the network edge to sanitize prompts/responses and block invalid requests before they hit GPUs.
Implemented with GKE Inference Gateway, Cloud Load Balancing and Google Kubernetes Engine to unify routing, governance and scaling for inference workloads.
takeaways: Higher sustained GPU utilization improves efficiency but can increase power density and cooling requirements—plan capacity, power and thermal provisioning accordingly.
AI-aware networking reduces wasted GPU cycles and total cost of ownership by routing around congested replicas and avoiding unnecessary inference runs.
Network-edge guardrails can prevent invalid or disallowed requests from consuming compute, cutting energy waste and operational cost while simplifying compliance.
Supporting these features requires enhanced network telemetry, low-latency routing, and QoS/SLAs—expect increased networking complexity and the need to upgrade monitoring and controls.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this is a short showcase of the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet running with NVIDIA DLSS 4 and Multi Frame Generation, presented with #RTXOn. The clip invites viewers to experience the title visually and credits DigitalDreamsyt for the footage.
bullets: Showcase of Where Winds Meet (open-world martial arts RPG) using DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation.
Promotes RTX-on visuals and upgraded NVIDIA upscaling/frame-generation tech.
No transcript available; description is brief and visual-focused.
Video credit: @DigitalDreamsyt.
takeaways: If DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation meaningfully improves rendering efficiency, expect potential reductions in energy consumed per rendered frame—relevant when estimating GPU power usage for visualization or AI workloads.

Improved frame-generation could raise sustained GPU utilization or peak loads in some scenarios; data center and substation planners should consider both average and peak power provisioning and cooling capacity when supporting dense GPU deployments.

Wider adoption of advanced GPU features can influence procurement cycles and demand for high-performance accelerators, with downstream implications for critical-minerals sourcing and lifecycle planning.
When integrating GPUs that leverage advanced upscaling/frame-generation, include power-monitoring and demand-response options in designs to capture efficiency gains while managing spikes.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this GE Vernova video highlights the importance of anticipating an aging steam turbine rotor’s remaining life and deciding what to do next to protect plant reliability. It positions the rotor as the backbone of a steam plant and directs viewers to GE Vernova’s rotor end-of-life resource while noting the company’s role in electrification and decarbonization.
bullets: Focuses on anticipating remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors and next-step decisions.
Frames the rotor as the backbone of steam-plant reliability.
Directs viewers to GE Vernova’s rotor end-of-life resource (rotor-EOL link).
Positions GE Vernova as supporting electrification and decarbonization efforts.
Includes channel subscription and social/website links for more information.
takeaways: Assess rotor remaining life proactively to reduce risk of unplanned outages that can affect grids and critical loads (e.g., data centers).
Incorporate rotor end-of-life planning into asset-management and CAPEX schedules to align maintenance windows and minimize service disruption.
Leverage vendor resources (like GE Vernova’s EOL guidance) when planning repairs, refurbishments, or replacements to maintain reliability.
Treat rotor health as a priority for long-term operational resilience and to support decarbonization goals via reliable thermal generation assets.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this KPMG ON AIR episode discusses shifts in the luxury goods market — rising emphasis on experiences over ownership, growth of “affordable luxury,” stronger ESG expectations, and the role of personalization and AI. Hosts Andrzej Marczak and Tomasz Wiśniewski highlight why Poland’s luxury sector is still expanding despite global headwinds and cover topics from luxury hospitality and art to future trends like AI and craftsmanship.
bullets: Global trends: ‘luxury fatigue’, concentration of spend (top 2% ~40% of market).
Demand for experiences and personalization (Gen Z prefers experiences to possessions).
ESG and responsible-luxury practices (eco-leathers, certifications) gaining importance.
Poland: growing but fragmented market; rising participation by aspirational consumers and young artists.
Future outlook: AI integration alongside traditional craftsmanship; luxury hospitality and tourism growth.
takeaways: Hospitality and premium tourism growth implies localized increases in peak electricity demand and reliability needs — consider capacity planning, resilience and microgrid options for hotels/spas.
Greater personalization and adoption of AI point to higher compute and low-latency needs; data center operators should anticipate increased workloads and prioritize energy-efficient infrastructure.

Stronger ESG requirements mean luxury brands will seek renewable-backed power and certified supply chains — grid operators and buyers should expand access to renewable PPAs, on-site generation and storage.
A fragmented but expanding market in Poland supports distributed energy resources and targeted electrification investments (behind-the-meter storage, EV charging) for premium locations.
Longer-term: balance investments in digital (AI/data centers) and physical (resilient on-site power, sustainable materials sourcing) infrastructure to meet luxury-sector expectations.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this short PJM video emphasizes that reliability has been PJM Interconnection’s primary mission since 1927. It invites viewers to learn how PJM works to make sure electricity is available when needed.
bullets: PJM Interconnection has prioritized reliability since 1927.
The video's stated focus is explaining how PJM ensures electricity is there when needed.
Content aims to educate viewers about PJM’s role in maintaining reliable power.
Target audience appears to be stakeholders and the public interested in grid reliability.
takeaways: If you operate in PJM territory, understanding PJM’s reliability role can inform site planning and operational coordination.
Data center and critical-load planners should account for PJM reliability practices when designing backup and resilience strategies.
Developers of renewables and storage should align project timelines and operational assumptions with PJM processes to support dependable delivery.
Grid/substation decision-makers can use PJM guidance to prioritize investments that reinforce overall system reliability.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video frames grid modernization as the challenge of expanding capacity for the energy transition while maintaining reliability, flexibility, and efficiency. Hitachi Energy positions digital-first power grid technologies as ways to improve grid stability, reduce downtime, and optimize performance across systems.
bullets: Power systems must balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency while scaling for the energy transition.
Hitachi Energy emphasizes digital technologies as central to grid modernization.
Digital solutions are presented as improving stability and reducing downtime.
Optimization of performance is framed as applicable 'at every level' of the power system.
The company offers more information via a provided link.
takeaways: Prioritize digital tools when planning substation or grid upgrades to improve stability and operational efficiency.
Frame capacity expansions to support renewables and storage without sacrificing reliability or increasing downtime.
Evaluate vendors on their ability to deliver end-to-end digital solutions that optimize performance across transmission, distribution, and critical loads (e.g., data centers).

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this Hitachi Energy video emphasizes that resilient industries depend on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. It states Hitachi Energy works with customers and partners to build smarter systems that improve productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Resilience built on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration.
Hitachi Energy collaborates with customers and partners on smarter system solutions.
Primary goals: improved productivity, enhanced reliability, and greater sustainability.
Applies across industrial operations (implications for power delivery and control systems).
Further details available via the provided link.
takeaways: Evaluate energy-efficiency and process-optimization measures to boost operational resilience.
Prioritize digital integration (monitoring, control, analytics) to improve reliability and uptime.
Consider partnerships with technology providers to deliver system-level productivity and sustainability gains.
Align capital decisions for substations, data center power, and storage with solutions that support both reliability and emissions goals.
